{{Infobox military person |name = Ghali Zakirovich Zakirov |native_name = Гали Закирович Закиров |birth_date = 1910 |death_date = February 1944 |birth_place = Bogatyje Saby village, [[Sabinsky District]], [[Tatarstan]] |death_place = [[Ukrainian SSR]] |allegiance = [[Soviet Union]] |branch = Airborne |serviceyears = 1941-1944 |rank = [[Junior sergeant]] |unit = [[3rd Guards Airborne Division]] |battles = [[World War II]] *[[Battle of Demyansk (1943)]] *[[Battle of Kursk]] *[[Operation Kutuzov]] *[[Battle of the Dnieper]] |awards = {{Hero of the Soviet Union}}{{Order of Lenin}} }}'''Ghali Zakirov''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Гали Закирович Закиров; 1910-February 1944) was a [[Tatars|Tatar]] [[Soviet people|Soviet]] soldier and [[Hero of the Soviet Union]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Герои Советского Союза -- Казахстанцы|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=S1kjAQAAMAAJ|publisher = Казахстан|date = 1968-01-01|language = ru|first = С.|last = Бейсембаев}}</ref> Zakirov was awarded the title for his actions in the [[Battle of the Dnieper]], where he reportedly killed over 100 German soldiers. He was killed in action a month after being awarded the title in January 1944.
== Early life == Zakirov was born in 1910 in [[Bogatyje Saby]] in [[Tatarstan]] to a peasant family. He received primary education and then became an agricultural worker. In 1940, he moved to Illinka village in the present-day [[Akzhar District]], where he worked in the [[machine and tractor station]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Институт Татарской Энциклопедии|url = http://www.ite.antat.ru/articles/gss/gss_104.shtml|website = www.ite.antat.ru|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":02">{{Cite book|url=http://www.az-libr.ru/index.htm?Persons&000/Src/0007/00e77417|title=Герои Советского Союза: Краткий биографический словарь|publisher=Voenizdat|year=1987|editor-last=Shkadov|editor-first=Ivan|volume=1 Abaev-Lubitsch|location=Moscow|language=Russian|trans-title=Heroes of the Soviet Union: A Brief Biographical Dictionary}}</ref>
== World War II == On 14 July 1941, Zakirov was drafted into the [[Red Army]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=20524|title=Закиров Гали Закирович|website=www.warheroes.ru|language=Russian|trans-title=Zakirov Ghali Zakirovich|accessdate=2015-09-13}}</ref><ref name=":02" /><ref name=":3">Irretrievable loss report, available online at [http://www.obd-memorial.ru/html/info.htm?id=61014031 obd-memorial.ru]</ref>In early 1942, he was seriously wounded.<ref name=":2" /> Zakirov spent six months convalescing in Bogatyje Saby and returned to the front in late 1942. <ref name=":2" />Zakirov served in the [[3rd Guards Airborne Division]] from February 1943.<ref name=":2" /> He fought in the [[Demyansk Pocket|Demyansk Offensive]] and [[Staraya Russa Offensive]] before the division was withdrawn to [[Maloarkhangelsk, Oryol Oblast|Maloarkhangelsk]] in April. In June 1943, the division became part of the [[Central Front (Soviet Union)|Central Front]]. During the [[Battle of Kursk]], the 3rd Guards Airborne were in the second line from 5 to 8 July but were moved into the front line from 8 to 12 July, where they, together with the [[307th Rifle Division]], stopped German counterattacks around [[Ponyri]] railway station. From 12 July to 18 August the division fought in [[Operation Kutuzov]].<ref name=":2" />
Zakirov participated in the [[Chernigov-Pripyat Offensive]], where the division [[Battle of the Dnieper|crossed]] the [[Desna River]] and then the [[Dnieper]] north of [[Kiev]]. In fighting to maintain its bridgehead over the Dnieper, Zakirov distinguished himself. By October 1943, he was a junior sergeant commanding a squad of the 3rd Battalion of the 8th Guards Airborne Regiment. <ref name=":2" /> On 5 October, near the village of Gubin, Zakirov and his squad advanced into the German trenches. Zakirov reportedly bayoneted 14 German soldiers. Continuing the attack, Zakirov and his squad reached the second line of defence. In the ensuing battle Zakirov's squad reportedly killed over 70 German soldiers, the remaining 50 reportedly fleeing. Zakirov reportedly hoisted a red flag on Height 125.7. The German troops launched three counterattacks, which Zakirov's squad of ten reportedly repulsed. During these battles, he reportedly killed over 100 German soldiers.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = ЗАКИРОВ Гали Закирович {{!}} Виртуальный музей Великой Отечественной войны Республики Татарстан|url = http://tatfrontu.ru/content/zakirov-gali-zakirovich|website = tatfrontu.ru|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
Zakirov later fought in the rest of the [[Battle of Kiev (1943)|Battle of Kiev]], and the [[Zhitomir–Berdichev Offensive]]. On 10 January 1944, he was awarded the [[Order of Lenin]]. He was killed in February 1944. <ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":02" />
Busts of him are displayed in Bogatyje Saby and Ilinka.<ref name=":2" />
== Personal life == Zakirov married Hazira before the war.<ref name=":3" />
